QuestionJSON.Question: Rebel has begun an internship at a company studying market trends. They notice that over the past four years, sales of a certain product increased during times when local unemployment rates decreased. Rebel decides to create an interactive line graph to demonstrate this correlation. What two variables should be plotted on the x and y-axes?
QuestionJSON.Answer1: Product sales on the x-axis, unemployment rates on the y-axis
QuestionJSON.Answer2: Product sales and unemployment rates on the x-axis, time on the y-axis
QuestionJSON.Answer3: Time on the x-axis, product sales and unemployment rates on the y-axis
QuestionJSON.Answer4: Unemployment rates on the x-axis, time on the y-axis
QuestionJSON.Explanation: When illustrating time-series data, it is conventional to place the independent variable 'time' on the x-axis and the dependent variable(s) - in this case, product sales and unemployment rates - on the y-axis in order to visually demonstrate how these vary over time.
